author: Hari

review: My friends just purchased this. So before I was going to purchase it I asked them if I could play with it for a while. After a glass of wine I kicked back and I played with it. I have invested so much money in Push2TV, Google's Chromecast, etc. I am not willing to put another dime into one of these so-called remote viewing products.  This is a Kindle fire on your TV using a remote control. That's it.  This is something that will be easily replaced in a couple months by Another gadget. It is not perfected by any means. I for one cannot be throwing around $99. So, after playing with this for awhile, I have come up with a most sincere conclusion that it is not worth $99 and I'd rather keep my money. I absolutely love technology and new fangled items on the market but this is a waste of money. There are other options out there that are just as good if not better And cost a lot less. I would wait until Kindle comes out with something else. This is not worth the money.
author: Gizmo

review: This is a very preliminary review as I just started using it.As a Prime member and not a heavy TV watcher seriously considering cutting the TV part of my cable bill I decided to give it a try. I have one Smart TV which already have access to Amazon, Netflix and many other apps but I also have a non-smart HD TV in my bedroom and given my light TV viewing habits I refuse to pay Comcast for another box when I already feel cheated paying for the service which I only keep because of bad over the air reception of local channels. I figure Fire TV will put that TV to use.The Good: The user interface, including voice search is a huge improvement over the typical smart TV and better than similar devices (Apple TV, Chromecast, Roku) which I don't have but I have seen in use many times at friends houses). Voice search seems to have some trouble understanding me but I have a heavy Cuban accent so I don't hold it against it, on the bright side it might help me improve my pronunciation, anyway be mindful of it if you are not a native English speaker.As of the hardware the box is really light and small, almost invisible and the addition of a optical audio (toslink) to connect to older AV receivers is welcome.The "improvement expected": Apps are very limited, even in comparison with a typical smart TV and even Amazon Fire tablets. I fully expect this issue to change over time. What it is most amazing and unforgivable is that the Amazon Cloud player is not available yet. I have the paid version of this great service and I have most of my music uploaded to it. I hope Amazon will soon make it available on Fire TV as it is in any other Android, Windows and Apple device.The Bad: No way to turn off the box except by unplugging the power. Yes, it goes to sleep after 30 minutes and the power consumption is probably very low but my concern is more with broadband consumption and security. Every piece of equipment connected to the Internet have security vulnerabilities, add a microphone (in the remote) and I could get uncomfortable. I hope a firmware update add a turn off option soon which I bet will be less harsh on the hardware that constant physical powering off.
